description: Extreme - Requires technical skills, business acumen, risk tolerance, fundraising ability, and resilience

fresher: *Note: As a founder, you don't have traditional "job titles" - you define your own role. Common designations

dailyWork: *Note: As a founder, there's no "typical" day. Work varies wildly based on stage.
Talking to potential customers, validating problem (10%)

learningCurve.description: **Extremely Steep and Continuous** - Starting a company requires learning everything: coding, product, design, sales, marketing, finance, legal, hiring, fundraising, leadership. Even experienced engineers find 80% of startup work unfamiliar. You're constantly in over your head, figuring things out on the fly. The learning never stops. What you don't know can kill your startup (bad unit economics, legal mistakes, wrong market). Most founders spend 2-3 years learning through failures before finding success. Only pursue if you love learning through painful trial and error.

factors: Financial instability: No steady income, burning savings
Uncertainty: No roadmap, no guarantee of success
Responsibility: Team depends on you for salaries, livelihood
Fundraising pressure: Constant pitch meetings, rejections (90%+ rejection rate)
Long hours: 70-90 hour weeks, always on call, work bleeds into life
mitigatingFactors: Autonomy: You're in control, building your vision
Purpose: Working on something you care deeply about
Community: Startup ecosystem is supportive (other founders understand)

thriveIf: You're comfortable with extreme uncertainty and risk
You're self-motivated and don't need external structure
You have high risk tolerance (financial and emotional)
You're resilient and bounce back from failures quickly
You're comfortable wearing many hats (tech + business + sales)
You love learning new things rapidly
You're passionate about solving a specific problem
avoidIf: You need financial stability and steady income
You prefer clear structure and defined work hours
You get demoralized by failure or rejection
You prefer specializing in one area (coding only)

collegeStrategy.title: Build Foundation
goals: *Year 1 (Build Foundation)
Learn programming (Python, web development)
Build 3-5 projects (apps, websites) - learn to ship
Understand basics of startups (read Paul Graham essays, YC library)
Attend entrepreneurship events, talks by founders
Join E-Cell or entrepreneurship club

collegeStrategy.title: Explore and Experiment
goals: *Year 2 (Explore and Experiment)
Build more substantial projects (full-stack apps with users)
Learn product thinking (not just coding, but what to build)
Attend startup events, hackathons (meet other builders)
Start following startup ecosystem (follow VCs, founders on Twitter)
Consider joining a startup as intern (₹15-30k/month, learn from inside)

collegeStrategy.title: Serious Experimentation
goals: *Year 3 (Serious Experimentation)
Start working on a real idea (identify problem worth solving)
Build MVP and get first users (friends, college students)
Summer internship at startup (₹30-60k/month, see how startups work)
Alternatively: Work on your own startup full-time in summer
Learn about fundraising (pitch decks, talking to investors)

collegeStrategy.title: Decide: Job or Startup
goals: *Year 4 (Decide: Job or Startup)
Option A: Launch startup, defer placements, go all-in
Option B: Take job offer, work on startup nights/weekends, quit after 6-12 months
Option C: Join a well-funded startup, learn for 2-3 years, then start your own
Apply to accelerators (YC, Antler, 100X.VC, etc.)
If starting: Raise pre-seed funding (₹20-50 lakhs from angels/accelerators)
